Summary I am a developer at Google. 
 
I have worked with software for over ten years. I have worked on a variety of systems including shrink-wrapped client-server software, content management, payment processing, and next generation SaaS systems leveraging service oriented architecture over a multi-tenant data architecture. 
 
I have worked with development team sizes ranging from 20 to over 200, providing technical leadership and helping to adapt to constantly changing requirements and delivery timelines. I have led development teams directly and contributed architectural advice and code to teams. I am comfortable working with other parts of the business to design solutions to meet business needs within resource constraints. 
 
I have worked extensively with performance and scalability on a variety of systems with a variety of deployment models and performance bottlenecks. I have transitioned systems from single-process to multi-process multi-node systems capable of handling orders of magnitude more load than before. One of these systems runs the front page of www.active.com today.  
 
My specialties are Java web applications, Java services, database systems, unit testing, load testing, .NET through 2.0, JavaScript, Scala, Unix, Bash scripting, SaaS, performance/scalability, threading/concurrency, asynchronous systems, internationalization, and more generally problem solving. I dabble in Ruby (on Rails and otherwise).  
 
I wake up in the morning excited to go to work because every day I get to try to solve new problems and overcome new challenges. 
 
I am proud to be a person to whom others come when they have technical questions. I am proud of my craftsmanship, my ability to rapidly master new technologies, and my ability to deliver a quality product on time. Summary I am a developer at Google.

Experience Senior Software Engineer Google May 2015  – Present (4 months) Mountain View Software Engineer Google October 2013  –  May 2015  (1 year 8 months) Mountain View Software Architect, Principal The Active Network January 2012  –  July 2013  (1 year 7 months) Helped select platform and architecture for new projects, worked extensively to tune Active's SOA, and worked to increase technology and platform convergence among Active projects. Provided technical analysis, guidance, mentoring, troubleshooting, and code/libraries for a variety of projects and problems. Worked to standardize architecture team candidate interview process. Worked extensively to explore options for order(s) of magnitude improvements to areas that limit application scalability. Software Architect, Enterprise The Active Network August 2010  –  December 2012  (2 years 5 months) I worked extensively on analysis of barriers to multi-language multi-currency operation. I created an advanced translation tool to search, edit, and analyze translations in our systems. I created an advanced Internationalization/Localization JavaScript library for use in HTML5/JS applications. I worked to integrated JavaScript unit testing and coverage analysis into build process. I continue to provide extensive support to a large development team, maintain tools, and help troubleshoot any problems encountered with the system. I am working on analysis of multi-node distributed performance with the ability to attribute service layer events back to parent operations and build an event timeline to faciltiate identification of performance and scalability issues in a highly distributed system. I am also working on how best to leverage our service layer for complex government solutions. Senior Software Engineer, Enterprise The Active Network September 2009  –  August 2010  (1 year) I joined the newly founded Enterprise Architecture team. I provided mentoring, technical assistance, libraries, and tools to a development team of ~200. I worked extensively to improve SaaS platform and aid teams in building and consuming services. I went to China for three months to run a team to build a cluster-friendly Java version of the consumer facing sales application with full internationalization support, superior scalability, and performance leveraging the capabilities of our services layer and distributed caching. I provided technical training sessions for the team on a variety of topics. Lead Software Engineer The Active Network July 2007  –  September 2009  (2 years 3 months) I joined the founding team for Active's next generation SaaS product. I worked with business owners to work from high level requirements identification through to the development and release of software. I worked to build Java web service SOA platform leveraging a multi-tenant data architecture partitioning data on service boundaries. I created a code generator to produce a strongly typed Flex API library for Java services to facilitate RIA Flex applications ability to consume Java services. I wrote a custom AMF/Java adapter to work around the fact that the Adobe version provided at the time tended to crash. I worked on design of order processing with a focus on deferring work for asynchronous processing later while maintaining accurate inventory. Senior Software Engineer The Active Network July 2007  –  July 2008  (1 year 1 month) I joined, then took leadership of, development of a Java based payment processing services. I worked directly with the VP of international operations and others to add support for additional tender types and currencies, automated deployment and configuration procedures, dramatically simplified build process, and added a multi-node synchronization mechanism to ensure "just once" batch processing with batches handled by any node in the cluster. This system handles millions of dollars in transactions daily. I continue to provide technical advice, code, and support to the team handling this system on a regular basis. Senior Software Engineer The Active Network March 2005  –  July 2007  (2 years 5 months) After Class Software was bought by The Active Network I worked on an ASP.NET Content Management System. I developed advanced output cache management framework. Added support for clustered operation. I performed load testing, performance/scalability analysis, performed substantial refactoring, and improved both performance and scalability. I was selected as technical expert to be sent to perform on-site performance analysis and tuning within months of joining the team. I analyzed request statistics, load patterns, and system hardware utilization patterns to generate hardware requirements to run www.active.com on a clustered instance of the system. Software Engineer Class Software Solutions September 2002  –  March 2005  (2 years 7 months) I coded primarily in VB6, C++, and ASP with some ASP.NET. I designed and implemented highly customizable data import module, performed performance analysis, and implemented major improvements to the consumer facing web module performance, and implemented a variety of new features. I implemented a code generator IDE plug-in to automate a number of common, manual, coding tasks. I rapidly rose to compete with another top developer on the team for #1 stack ranking on the team. Summary At Google, I am part of the deep learning project (aka "Google Brain"​) where I'm trying to solve Computer Vision & world understanding using deep networks. The underlying technology is used in various ways in Google Photos, YouTube, image search, StreetView etc. Full list of publications: http://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=wfGiqXEAAAAJ Summary At Google, I am part of the deep learning project (aka "Google Brain"​) where I'm trying to solve Computer Vision & world understanding using deep networks. The underlying technology is used in various ways in Google Photos, YouTube, image search, StreetView etc. Full list of publications: http://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=wfGiqXEAAAAJ At Google, I am part of the deep learning project (aka "Google Brain"​) where I'm trying to solve Computer Vision & world understanding using deep networks. The underlying technology is used in various ways in Google Photos, YouTube, image search, StreetView etc. Full list of publications: http://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=wfGiqXEAAAAJ Experience Senior Software Engineer Google July 2015  – Present (2 months) San Francisco Bay Area Google Brain team: understanding the world with neural networks. Senior Software Engineer Google August 2012  –  July 2015  (3 years) San Francisco Bay Area Computer Vision using deep neural networks. Main applications are personal photo search & image search. Applied research resulting in >4 publications and 2 patent applications since I joined. Production impact by developing a model which is used to annotate all images at Google with content-based labels. 
 
The main body of work is concentrated on solving the scalable image annotation and detection problem. That is, we need to annotate all the images at Google with high precision labels using as little CPU time as possible. To this end, we developed novel state of the art detection frameworks that use convolutional neural networks at their core. Our latest work is on Scalable Object Detection using Deep Neural Networks (http://arxiv.org/abs/1312.2249), which is a system that can infer class-agnostic regions of interesting very efficiently. Scientist Yahoo! March 2011  –  August 2012  (1 year 6 months) Sunnyvale, CA Solving the problem of federated search: automatically learn from click data what type of content to slot where on the search results page. Deciding this in real-time (20ms). 
 
In charge of all the modelling details: coming up with better models, adding features, removing features, automated feature selection/understanding, using better latent embedding methods, exploration/exploitation trade-offs, unbiased offline evaluation, efficient parallel training (on O(10^8) or more examples), automatic model selection, better measuring and interpreting implicit user feedback, personalization, etc. 
 
Product is live and serving 100% of Yahoo Search US traffic (10^7 -- 10^8 queries per day), improving user metrics and revenue considerably. Software Engineer Google June 2012  –  November 2014  (2 years 6 months) Greater New York City Area After graduating college, I returned to Google as a full-time employee. Software Engineering Intern Google June 2011  –  September 2011  (4 months) Greater New York City Area The summer before my senior year of college I interned at Google, working on Google Apps Script, a cloud-based JavaScript platform targeting Google Docs and Apps services. Co-Op Developer in DIS Division Argonne National Laboratory June 2010  –  September 2010  (4 months) Greater Chicago Area I added new, user-visible features to an in-house charting library, investigated ORM tools for a new project, and documented some existing database access code (JDBC for the frontend and Oracle Pro*C for the backend). Web Application Developer North Central College September 2009  –  March 2010  (7 months) Greater Chicago Area While studying at North Central College, I worked part time for several months at their Information Technology Services department, collaborating with full-time Web development staff to completely rewrite the school's online event calendar. Experience Senior Software Engineer Google January 2014  – Present (1 year 8 months) Greater Seattle Area I work for Google Compute Engine - infrastructure-as-a-service on Google's infrastructure (https://cloud.google.com/compute/). My areas of focus has been the following: 
 
1) Encryption key management for disks, snapshots, images, and other sensitive user data. 
2) IPSec VPN API to enable secure connectivity from VM in Compute Engine virtual network to customer on-premise networks. 
3) HTTP/HTTPS Load Balancing API. Senior Software Engineer Google June 2013  –  January 2014  (8 months) San Francisco Bay Area I worked on designing and prototyping next generation serving stack for Google CloudSQL. Software Engineer Google August 2010  –  May 2013  (2 years 10 months) San Francisco Bay Area I worked for Google CloudSQL - a fully-managed, highly available and universally accessible database-as-a-service on Google’s infrastructure (https://cloud.google.com/sql/).  
 
I worked on various aspects of the product. Following are few highlights I owned: 
1) Native MySQL connectivity from AppEngine, Compute Engine and public Internet. 
2) Multi-homing for CloudSQL instance for low latency from AppEngine and Compute Engine. 
3) Automated failover of CloudSQL instance during data center outage.  
4) Integration between CloudSQL and Cloud storage for import and export of MySQL dump. 
5) Per-usage and package billing pipeline for CloudSQL. 
6) Audit trail for CloudSQL admin operations. Research Assistant Northwestern Network Group August 2005  –  August 2010  (5 years 1 month) Evanston, IL I worked on various aspects of computer networks during my PhD at Northwestern University. Following are few highlights: 
 
(1) Designed a CDN-based data delivery approach in P2P that significantly reduces the inter-AS traffic volume generated by network oblivious P2P applications. Developed a monitoring BitTorrent client to monitor fine-grained swarm dynamics of large number of torrents. 
 
(2) Designed a DoS-resilient TCP stack to mitigate large-scale poisoning attacks in the Internet. 
 
(3) Investigated application and transport layer techniques to improve response times of thin-stream TCP applications. 
 
(4) Challenged the need of exponential backoff mechanism in TCP through analytical modeling, large-scale simulations, and Emulab experiments. 
 
Publications: 
(1) "P2P as a CDN: A new service model for file sharing", A. Mondal, I. Trestian, Z. Qin, and A. Kuzmanovic, Journal of Computer Networks, Volume 56 Issue 14, September, 2012. 
 
(2) "Understanding End-user Perception of Network Problems", J S Miller, A Mondal, R Potharaju, P Dinda, A Kuzmanovic, ACM SIGCOMM Workshop on Measurements Up the STack (W-MUST), August, 2011. 
 
(3) "Adding Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN) Capabilities to TCP's SYN/ACK Packets", A. Kuzmanovic, A Mondal, S. Floyd, and K.K. Ramakrishnan, RFC 5562, 2009. 
 
(4) "Upgrading Mice to Elephants: Effects and End-Point Solutions" A. Mondal and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking (ToN) 2010. 
 
(5) "Removing Exponential Backoff from TCP", A. Mondal and A. Kuzmanovic, ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communications Review (CCR) 2008. 
 
(6) "A Poisoning-Resilient TCP Stack", A. Mondal and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE ICNP 2007. 
 
(7) "When TCP Friendliness Becomes Harmful", A. Mondal and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE INFOCOM 2007. Research Intern Microsoft Research July 2008  –  September 2008  (3 months) Redmond, WA I developed a distributed measurement framework, SureCall, to collect packet traces of emulated VoIP and video conferencing traffic in the Internet. We recruited few dozens of volunteers around the world to deploy SureCall on their machines to collect real data. We analyzed the packet traces to quantify the impact of various network scenarios on the performance of audio/video conferencing.  
 
We further designed, implemented and experimented using SureCall platform a WiFi-relay solution which uses application-level replication through relays to significantly improve VoIP performance for WiFi users. 
 
Publications: 
(1) "SureCall: Towards Glitch-Free Real-time Audio/Video Conferencing" A. Mondal, R. Cutler, C. Huang, J. Li, and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE IWQoS 2010 
 
(2) "A Case for WiFi Relay: Improving VoIP Quality for WiFi Users", A. Mondal, C. Huang, J. Li, M. Jain, and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE ICC 2010 
 
Patent: 
(1) Data Communication With Compensation for Packet Loss, US patent No: 20110134909. Research Intern Hewlett-Packard Laboratories July 2007  –  September 2007  (3 months) Palo Alto, CA I designed a framework to find routes that meet individual QoS metrics efficiently and scalably under multiple QoS constraints. Built a functional prototype on UNIX platform. 
 
Publication: 
(1) "Supporting Application Network Flows with Multiple QoS Constraints" A. Mondal, P. Sharma, S. Banerjee, and A. Kuzmanovic, IEEE IWQoS 2009. 
 
Patent: 
(2) Flow Path Discovery In Network To Guarantee Multiple Metric QoS Constraints, US Patent No: 20100278069. Summary During my work at Akamai and Google and during my PhD I have worked on the design and implementation of large scalable fault-tolerant distributed systems. In my work I have tackled complex problems of load-balancing, fairness, fault-tolerance, distributed caching and efficient network routing. In addition, I have strong mathematical background (both from MIT and Columbia) and have worked on probabilistic modeling and analysis of systems. 
 
Recently, I have augmented my skills set with big data analysis problems at the Google AdWords Optimizations team.

PhD student /computer networks researcher Columbia University September 2003  –  November 2010  (7 years 3 months) I conducted research in the area of Peer-to-Peer (P2P) networks, Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) and large distributed systems. I have vast experience in large-scale system design and implementation as well as algorithmic design and analysis. In the past I worked at Akamai where I designed and built several critical subsystems that support content delivery across thousands of the Akamai servers.  
 
My PhD (completed in 2010) research revolved around quality of service in P2P file-sharing networks. As part of my thesis I built, deployed and analyzed large-scale P2P systems, ran experiments on live P2P systems, and studied interaction of controlled P2P agents inside live P2P networks. I designed P2P file-sharing and streaming algorithms that significantly improved performance and fairness of P2P systems and built probabilistic models that described the system behavior. Software Development Engineer Google February 2011  –  November 2012  (1 year 10 months) Mountain View, California Software Engineer, Web Search Infrastructure Senior Software Engineer Yahoo! Search 2010  –  March 2011  (1 year) Sunnyvale California - Highlights: 
∗ Hacked Yahoo! Search’s skin generation tool and turned it into a fully distributed system by splitting the skin generation tasks across idle development boxes (worker nodes). This lowered the generation time from 12 minutes (per market) to 20 seconds. 
∗ Hacked Firebug to turn it into a Firefox extension to debug applications built on top of Yahoo’s proprietary framework “GSP2”. 
∗ Gave tech-talks in top universities like MIT and Carnegie Mellon aimed to recruit top talent for Yahoo! 
 
- Query Intent & Analysis (QIA) team: 
∗ Wrote several prototypes, bucket-tests and production features for Yahoo! Search. Features included server-side, browser-side and workflow changes. All features passed QA and were launched on-schedule. 
∗ Participated in the design of live experiments (bucket tests) by guiding implementation decisions at design stage. 
∗ Proactively collaborated with members of the Science and Statistics teams throughout the live cycle of the bucket-tests to make sure their needs were met by the bucket-tests and the collected data. 
 
- Buildmaster for Yahoo! Search: 
∗ Coordinated and executed Yahoo! Search’ bi-weekly builds. Effectively collaborated with all parties involved, including fellow engineers, QA, operations, project managers and other stakeholders. 
∗ Tracked down and troubleshot server-side, browser-side and performance issues at build/deploy time. 
 
- Other activities: 
∗ Served as primary technical interviewer for the Search Front-end team. 
∗ Coached and guided new members of the team throughout their ramp-up period. 
∗ Tutored university students during their internships with Yahoo! Search.

Experience Sr Software Engineer, Maps for Business (Google Maps Engine and Earth Enterprise) Google November 2013  – Present (1 year 10 months) Mountain View, CA For several months at the start of this period I assisted in the development and support of one of Google's oldest Geo products -- "Earth Enterprise" provides enterprise customers of Google Earth with the ability to generate their own globes from proprietary data. The product is used by government agencies and infrastructure-oriented businesses throughout the world. 
 
I subsequently joined the Google Maps Engine "Core" team. GME is Google's premier enterprise-grade solution for geographic data processing in the cloud. In January 2015 Google announced that GME will be discontinued and the service shut down in January 2016. So for the rest of 2015 I am part of the GME "Sunset Cruise" team. 
 
One of advantage of the "Sunset Cruise" is that we have considerable liberty to look into new areas for the future -- I am currently exploring the development of mobile (Android) applications. Summary I'm a Senior Software Engineer at Google, on the Google Docs team since 2010. My work spans all major Docs platforms: server-side, web front-end and Mobile. My current project is the Google Sheets iOS app. I also hack on infrastructure projects and developer power tools (Vim extensions, command-line tools etc). 
 
My day job involves switching regularly between different programming languages and different platforms. Some of the languages I've worked with recently include: C, C++, Java, Javascript, Objective-C, Objective-C++, Python, Perl, Bash, etc. 
 
I've been an active open source developer for over 15 years. You can see a lot of my recent activity on GitHub (http://github.com/patspam).

Summary I am a senior software engineer presently employed by Google Inc. in Mountain View, CA. I graduated from the University of Texas at Austin with a double-major in both computer science and biochemistry, where I had the opportunity of working in the confluence of those fields in the area of computational quantum chemistry. During that time as a student I was also employed part-time at the University maintaining the high-performance computer clusters at the Institute for Computer Engineering and Sciences there. After graduation, I joined the DirectX driver team at NVIDIA Corp. and moved to the greater Bay Area of California. 2.5 years later, I moved on to Google, where I am presently situated. 
 
My interest in computing is making software run fast, which increasingly means distributed computing and massive parallelism. This has many applications, particularly computer graphics (another interest of mine), but it is already an interesting challenge in and of itself.
